item.title: Killer of Chris Hani, Anti-Apartheid Activist, Is Granted Parole
item.description: Some South Africans expressed outrage over the paroling of Janusz Walus, who had been serving a life sentence for the 1993 killing.
item.dc:creator: SEWELL CHAN
item.media:description: Janusz Walus, the convicted killer of South African anti-apartheid leader Chris Hani, testified at a Truth and Reconciliation Commission hearing in 1997. Mr. Walus was granted parole on Thursday.

item.title: Iran’s Missile Tests and the Nuclear Deal
item.description: Questions and answers on Iran’s recent missile tests and how its actions apply to the parameters of the nuclear agreement that took effect in January.
item.dc:creator: RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: Where’s My Mercedes? Egypt’s Financial Crisis Hits the Rich
item.description: Wealthy Egyptians have been among President Abdel Fattah el-Sisi’s most ardent supporters. But that loyalty is being tested as the economy struggles.
item.dc:creator: DECLAN WALSH
item.media:credit: Sima Diab for The New York Times
item.media:description: A Porsche showroom in Cairo. The government is losing support from Egypt’s wealthy as the severe shortage of foreign currency cripples businesses, impedes luxury imports and crimps their lifestyles.

item.title: Op-Ed Columnist: The Map of My Life
item.description: Why I hoard redundant maps as otherworldly as old sewing machines or outsize transistor radios.
item.dc:creator: ROGER COHEN

item.title: Germany Obtains List of Foreigners Suspected of Fighting for ISIS
item.description: Officials said they believed it was authentic, but they declined to give any details about where it came from or the identities of those on it.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: MELISSA EDDY
item.media:description: Thomas de Maizière, Germany’s interior minister, said the country hoped the information in the list could serve as evidence against several citizens facing charges related to terrorist activities.

item.title: Obama and Justin Trudeau of Canada Unveil Efforts to Fight Climate Change
item.description: The two leaders announced commitments to reduce planet-warming emissions of methane and pledged cooperation in preserving the Arctic.
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL D. SHEAR and CORAL DAVENPORT
item.media:description: Prime Minister Justin Trudeau of Canada and President Obama at the arrival ceremony on the South Lawn of the White House on Thursday.

item.title: Head of VW’s U.S. Unit Is Out, and Dealers Are Alarmed
item.description: Michael Horn has played a crucial role in rebuilding Volkswagen’s relationship with its dealership network, gaining the support of the sales force.
item.dc:creator: JAD MOUAWAD
item.media:description: Michael Horn, now the former chief of Volkswagen’s American operations, last November. He is the latest executive to leave the automaker, which is dealing with the fallout from its diesel emissions scandal.

item.title: Chinese Crackdown on Lawyers and Activists Is Criticized at U.N.
item.description: The United States and 11 other countries on the Human Rights Council expressed alarm at the sweeping arrests of activists and lawyers and the treatment of several Hong Kong residents who vanished.
item.dc:creator: NICK CUMMING-BRUCE

item.title: Fukushima Keeps Fighting Radioactive Tide 5 Years After Disaster
item.description: A full cleanup of the site is expected to take at least 40 years according to the government’s timetable, and a century by other estimates.
item.dc:creator: JONATHAN SOBLE
item.media:description: Little is left on a stretch of tsunami-scarred land in the vicinity of Fukushima Daiichi, the ruined and radioactive nuclear power plant in northeastern Japan.

item.title: Spanish Castle Is Spared From Collapse, but Not Criticism
item.description: The restoration of Matrera Castle, perched on a ridge in the Andalusia region, has infuriated locals and provoked the ire of some conservationists.
item.dc:creator: MARK A. WALSH
item.media:description: The Matrera Castle in southern Spain after its restoration. Images of the castle before and after the restoration have recently fueled bemusement and ridicule on social media.

item.title: Letter From Europe: Facing Migrant Crisis, E.U. Makes a Dubious Deal With Turkey
item.description: The European Union once counted on Muammar el-Qaddafi of Libya to block migrants from its shores. Now it looks to Recep Tayyip Erdogan of Turkey.
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis
item.dc:creator: STEVEN ERLANGER
item.media:description: President Recep Tayyip Erdogan bargained hard with European officials in a deal that would effectively make Turkey the gatekeeper for migrants hoping to reach the Continent.

item.title: Russia Tricked Ukrainian Captive Into Easing Hunger Strike, Lawyer Says
item.description: Nadya V. Savchenko, a military pilot, drank water after receiving a letter from Ukraine’s president, news outlets said, but his office said he sent no such document.
item.dc:creator: ANDREW E. KRAMER
item.media:description: Nadya V. Savchenko delivered her final statement to the court in the southern Russian town of Donetsk, on Wednesday.

item.title: Western Hostages in Philippines Plead for Their Lives in New Video
item.description: The two Canadians and Norwegian man being held by Islamic extremists said they would be killed in a month if their kidnappers’ demands were not met.
item.dc:creator: FLOYD WHALEY
item.media:credit: Eastmincom, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: From left, Kjartan Sekkingstad of Norway and John Ridsdel and Robert Hall of Canada are being held by Islamic extremists in the southern Philippines.

item.title: Capiatá Journal: The Dream of Treasure Keeps Paraguayans Digging
item.description: Tales of gold buried more than a century ago, however dubious, entrance hunters of all persuasions while the government endeavors to protect cultural artifacts.
item.dc:creator: JONATHAN GILBERT
item.media:description: A hole in the yard of a property belonging to Juan Alberto Díaz, a full-time treasure hunter in Capiatá, Paraguay.

item.title: Obama and Justin Trudeau of Canada Unveil Efforts to Fight Climate Change
item.description: The two leaders announced commitments to reduce planet-warming emissions of methane and pledged cooperation in preserving the Arctic.
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL D. SHEAR and CORAL DAVENPORT
item.media:description: Prime Minister Justin Trudeau of Canada and President Obama at the arrival ceremony on the South Lawn of the White House on Thursday.

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: New Zealand: One Nation Under a Beach Towel?
item.description: Prime Minister John Key has spent millions trying to change a flag that Kiwis want to keep.
item.dc:creator: STEVE BRAUNIAS

item.title: Tibetan Entrepreneur Has Been Illegally Detained, Family Says
item.description: The activist, Tashi Wangchuk, has highlighted the dearth of meaningful Tibetan education. He has been in custody for 44 days.
item.dc:creator: EDWARD WONG
item.media:credit: Gilles Sabrie for The New York Times
item.media:description: Tashi Wangchuk, a Tibetan activist, at a horse festival in Yushu, a Tibetan area of Qinghai Province, China, last year. He is said to have been illegally detained by the police for over a month.

item.title: Loyalist of Aung San Suu Kyi in Line for Myanmar Presidency
item.description: A party official stresses that the new leader would be a subordinate to Ms. Aung San Suu Kyi, who is barred from holding that office.
item.dc:creator: WAI MOE and RICHARD C. PADDOCK
item.media:description: Parliamentary members of the National League for Democracy awaiting their party’s nominations for the government’s top posts on Thursday in Naypyidaw, Myanmar.

item.title: Obama Criticizes the ‘Free Riders’ Among America’s Allies
item.description: In interviews with The Atlantic, President Obama took an unusually blunt tone in expressing consternation with Middle Eastern nations and the demands placed on the U.S.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: MARK LANDLER
item.media:description: Pro-Russian rebels in eastern Ukraine in 2014. President Obama defended the United States’ actions toward Russia over its aggression in Ukraine.

item.title: World Briefing: 34 Countries Need Food Aid, Report Says
item.description: The report said conflicts in Iraq, Syria, Yemen, Somalia and the Central African Republic had taken a heavy toll on agricultural production.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS
